Pregnant women need compassion, not cruel lawsSujatha Prabhakaran
 |  Sarasota Herald-TribuneCompassion. Not politics. As a physician who provides abortion care to my patients I believe medical knowledge and compassion for each patient’s individual circumstances – not politics – should guide decisions about access to abortion care.But once again politicians in Tallahassee are trying to insert themselves in the exam room between patients and their trusted physicians. These misguided politicians are again working to impose restrictions on the gestational age at which a woman can make the personal decision to end a pregnancy. These restrictions often affect patients at a time in their lives that are among their most difficult, which makes these restrictions not only medically unsafe but also cruel to the families they affect.  Politicians don’t know the stories of the individual patients they are hurting with these restrictions. They don’t sit with them and hold their hands as they struggle to do the right thing by their families and their faith. I do. I know these families. I know their stories and their struggles. And I know they won’t be served by this dangerous and hurtful law. I recently had a patient – with a planned and wanted pregnancy – who was diagnosed at 21 weeks with pulmonary hypoplasia due to renal agenesis. What this means is that once her baby was delivered he would be unable to breath air and would suffocate to death. I ask you: Who would be served by forcing a woman and her family in this terrible situation to carry her pregnancy to term? I can tell you that this patient didn’t consider herself “pro choice” until she went through this experience and came to understand firsthand that every situation, every pregnancy is different. I met with a state senator who had signed on as a sponsor of a 20-week abortion ban that year. My patient was one of his constituents. When I told him this story he acknowledged that he really didn’t understand the potential implications of what he was supporting. The bill failed that year and I hope it will again this year.Recently women from around the country who had abortions later in pregnancy spoke out against the abortion ban bill currently being considered in Florida – Senate Bill 744 and House Bill 351. Dana Peirce from Yarmouth, Maine, is a wife and a mother of two living children. In 2019 – 32 weeks into what had been a normal pregnancy – she and her family went to what they expected to be a routine ultrasound.That’s when they found out their son, Cameron, had lethal skeletal dysplasia. This is another condition that causes babies to be unable to breath outside the womb; their rib cages are too small and leave no room for their lungs to expand. Cameron also had a broken femur and evidence of other healed fractures.Dana’s son was suffering and would only continue to suffer until he was born – at which point he would have suffocated to death. Dana and her husband decided that they couldn’t in good conscience allow their son’s needless suffering to continue.They decided to have an abortion but the law wouldn’t allow it in Maine. So on top of the trauma of learning their son was actively suffering and wouldn’t survive, they had to embark on a cross-country odyssey to Boulder, Colorado, to get the care they needed.Hadleigh Tweedall from Franklin, Tennessee, shared her story about another wanted pregnancy that went tragically wrong.“Multiple specialists told me it was medically impossible for our daughter to survive longer than a few more weeks of pregnancy," she said. "Every ounce of excitement and future dream I had about our growing family was taken from me in a matter of minutes."Added Tweedall: "I am a Christian and I believe in miracles, but I also trust modern medicine. I could not stand the thought of my daughter suffering in the one place she should feel safest. I could not bond with her longer and watch my belly grow even bigger, only to say our inevitable goodbye. I could not labor for hours to deliver our dead daughter.”As an OB-GYN I hear these stories and see my patients’ distress. I’m not motivated by politics but rather by compassion to address their individual needs and provide the best care I can.I urge you to remember these women and others like them. When faced with difficult, often heart-wrenching decisions about pregnancy, these patients deserve understanding and support – not dangerous and harmful legislation that is politically motivated.Dr. Sujatha Prabhakaran is medical director of Planned Parenthood of Southwest and Central Florida, which is based in Sarasota. She is an affiliate assistant professor in the University of South Florida's Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology.
